description: Explore cell structure, organelles, membrane transport, cellular respiration, and photosynthesis

slides.title: Welcome to Cell Biology
slides.content:
# Introduction to Cell Biology

Welcome to **Cell Biology** - the study of life's fundamental unit!

## What You Will Learn:
- **Cell Structure** - Components of cells
- **Organelles** - Specialized structures
- **Membrane Transport** - How substances move
- **Cellular Respiration** - Energy production
- **Photosynthesis** - Making food from light
- **Cell Division** - How cells reproduce

> **Fun Fact:** Your body contains about 37 trillion cells!

## Cell Theory:
1. All living things are made of cells
2. Cells are the basic unit of life
3. All cells come from pre-existing cells

## Prokaryotes vs Eukaryotes:

| Feature | Prokaryote | Eukaryote |
|---------|------------|----------|
| Nucleus | No | Yes |
| Size | 1-10 um | 10-100 um |
| Organelles | Few | Many |
| Examples | Bacteria | Animals, plants |

slides.title: Cell Organelles
slides.content:
# Cell Organelles

## Nucleus:
- Contains DNA
- Controls cell activities
- Nuclear envelope with pores
- Nucleolus makes ribosomes

## Mitochondria:
- Powerhouse of the cell
- ATP production
- Double membrane
- Own DNA (maternal)

## Ribosomes:
- Protein synthesis
- Free or on rough ER

## Endoplasmic Reticulum:
**Rough ER:** Has ribosomes, makes proteins
**Smooth ER:** Makes lipids, detoxifies

## Golgi Apparatus:
- Packages and modifies proteins
- Sends to destinations

## Lysosomes:
- Digestive enzymes
- Break down waste

## Vacuoles:
- Storage
- Large central vacuole in plants

## Chloroplasts (plants):
- Photosynthesis
- Contains chlorophyll

## Cell Wall (plants, fungi, bacteria):
- Rigid outer layer
- Support and protection

slides.title: Cell Membrane
slides.content:
# Cell Membrane

## Structure:

**Fluid Mosaic Model:**
- Phospholipid bilayer
- Proteins embedded (mosaic)
- Fluid - molecules move laterally

## Phospholipids:
- Hydrophilic head (polar)
- Hydrophobic tails (nonpolar)
- Self-assemble in water

## Membrane Proteins:

| Type | Function |
|------|----------|
| Channel | Allow specific ions through |
| Carrier | Transport molecules |
| Receptor | Receive signals |
| Enzyme | Catalyze reactions |
| Recognition | Cell identity (glycoproteins) |

## Other Components:

**Cholesterol:**
- Maintains fluidity
- Stabilizes membrane

**Carbohydrates:**
- Attached to proteins/lipids
- Cell recognition

## Functions:
1. Selective barrier
2. Transport
3. Communication
4. Cell recognition
5. Enzyme activity
6. Cell adhesion

slides.title: Cell Structure Quiz
slides.quizQuestion: Which organelle is called the 'powerhouse of the cell'?

slides.title: Membrane Transport
slides.content:
# Membrane Transport

## Passive Transport (no energy):

### Diffusion:
- Movement from high to low concentration
- Down concentration gradient
- Until equilibrium

### Osmosis:
- Diffusion of water
- Through selectively permeable membrane

**Solution Types:**
- **Hypertonic:** Higher solute outside (cell shrinks)
- **Hypotonic:** Lower solute outside (cell swells)
- **Isotonic:** Equal concentrations (no change)

### Facilitated Diffusion:
- Uses membrane proteins
- Still no energy required
- Channel or carrier proteins

## Active Transport (requires energy):

### Sodium-Potassium Pump:
- 3 Na+ out, 2 K+ in
- Uses ATP
- Maintains cell potential

### Bulk Transport:

**Endocytosis:** Taking in
- Phagocytosis (cell eating)
- Pinocytosis (cell drinking)
- Receptor-mediated

**Exocytosis:** Releasing
- Vesicles fuse with membrane
- Contents released outside

slides.title: Cellular Respiration Overview
slides.content:
# Cellular Respiration

**Purpose:** Convert glucose to ATP (usable energy)

## Overall Equation:
```
C6H12O6 + 6O2 -> 6CO2 + 6H2O + ATP
```

## Three Stages:

### 1. Glycolysis (cytoplasm):
- Glucose -> 2 Pyruvate
- Net: 2 ATP, 2 NADH
- Anaerobic (no O2 needed)

### 2. Krebs Cycle (mitochondrial matrix):
- Pyruvate -> CO2
- Produces: 2 ATP, 8 NADH, 2 FADH2
- Per glucose molecule

### 3. Electron Transport Chain (inner membrane):
- NADH, FADH2 donate electrons
- Produces: 34 ATP
- Requires O2 (final electron acceptor)

## ATP Yield:

| Stage | ATP |
|-------|-----|
| Glycolysis | 2 |
| Krebs Cycle | 2 |
| ETC | 34 |
| **Total** | **38** |

(Theoretical maximum, actual ~30-32)

## Key Molecules:
- NAD+/NADH - electron carrier
- FAD/FADH2 - electron carrier
- ATP/ADP - energy currency

slides.title: Fermentation
slides.content:
# Fermentation

When oxygen is unavailable, cells use **fermentation**.

## Why Fermentation?
- Regenerates NAD+ for glycolysis
- Allows continued ATP production
- Only 2 ATP (vs 38 aerobic)

## Types:

### Lactic Acid Fermentation:
```
Glucose -> 2 Lactate + 2 ATP
```

**Occurs in:**
- Muscle cells (during intense exercise)
- Some bacteria (yogurt, cheese)

**Effect:** Causes muscle fatigue and burning

### Alcoholic Fermentation:
```
Glucose -> 2 Ethanol + 2 CO2 + 2 ATP
```

**Occurs in:**
- Yeast
- Some plants

**Uses:**
- Bread (CO2 causes rising)
- Beer, wine (alcohol production)
- Biofuel (ethanol)

## Comparison:

| Type | Product | ATP | Organisms |
|------|---------|-----|----------|
| Aerobic | CO2, H2O | 38 | Most eukaryotes |
| Lactic acid | Lactate | 2 | Muscles, bacteria |
| Alcoholic | Ethanol, CO2 | 2 | Yeast |

slides.title: Photosynthesis
slides.content:
# Photosynthesis

**Purpose:** Convert light energy to chemical energy (glucose)

## Overall Equation:
```
6CO2 + 6H2O + Light -> C6H12O6 + 6O2
```

## Location:
- Chloroplasts (in leaves)
- Thylakoid membranes (light reactions)
- Stroma (Calvin cycle)

## Two Stages:

### Light Reactions (thylakoid):
- Capture light energy
- Split water (O2 released)
- Produce ATP and NADPH

**Key steps:**
1. Light hits chlorophyll
2. Electrons excited
3. Electron transport chain
4. Chemiosmosis makes ATP
5. NADP+ reduced to NADPH

### Calvin Cycle (stroma):
- Uses ATP and NADPH
- Fixes CO2 into glucose
- Also called C3 pathway

**Key steps:**
1. Carbon fixation (CO2 + RuBP)
2. Reduction (uses ATP, NADPH)
3. Regeneration of RuBP

## Factors Affecting:
- Light intensity
- CO2 concentration
- Temperature
- Water availability

slides.title: Cell Cycle
slides.content:
# Cell Cycle

## Stages:

### Interphase (90% of cycle):

**G1 Phase:**
- Cell growth
- Normal functions
- Prepares for DNA replication

**S Phase:**
- DNA synthesis (replication)
- Chromosomes duplicated

**G2 Phase:**
- More growth
- Prepares for mitosis

### M Phase (Mitosis):
- Nuclear division
- 4 stages

## Cell Cycle Control:

**Checkpoints:**
- G1 checkpoint (most important)
- G2 checkpoint
- M checkpoint

**Regulators:**
- Cyclins
- CDKs (cyclin-dependent kinases)

**Growth Factors:**
- External signals to divide

## Cell Cycle Problems:

**Cancer:**
- Uncontrolled cell division
- Checkpoints fail
- Mutations in regulatory genes

slides.title: Mitosis
slides.content:
# Mitosis

**Purpose:** Make identical copies for growth/repair

## Stages:

### 1. Prophase:
- Chromatin condenses to chromosomes
- Nuclear envelope breaks down
- Spindle forms

### 2. Metaphase:
- Chromosomes line up at equator
- Spindle attached to centromeres

### 3. Anaphase:
- Sister chromatids separate
- Move to opposite poles

### 4. Telophase:
- Nuclear envelopes reform
- Chromosomes decondense
- Spindle disappears

### Cytokinesis:
- Cytoplasm divides
- Animal: cleavage furrow
- Plant: cell plate

## Result:
- 2 identical daughter cells
- Same chromosome number as parent
- Diploid -> Diploid

## Memory Aid:
**PMAT:** Prophase, Metaphase, Anaphase, Telophase

slides.title: Meiosis
slides.content:
# Meiosis

**Purpose:** Make gametes (sex cells) with half chromosomes

## Two Divisions:

### Meiosis I (Reductional):

**Prophase I:**
- Homologous pairs synapse
- Crossing over occurs

**Metaphase I:**
- Homologous pairs line up

**Anaphase I:**
- Homologous chromosomes separate

**Telophase I:**
- Two haploid cells

### Meiosis II (Like mitosis):

**Prophase II, Metaphase II, Anaphase II, Telophase II**
- Sister chromatids separate

## Result:
- 4 haploid daughter cells
- Genetically different
- Diploid -> Haploid

## Sources of Variation:

1. **Crossing over:** Genes exchanged between homologs
2. **Independent assortment:** Random orientation of pairs
3. **Random fertilization:** Any sperm + any egg

## Comparison:

| Feature | Mitosis | Meiosis |
|---------|---------|--------|
| Purpose | Growth | Gametes |
| Divisions | 1 | 2 |
| Daughters | 2 | 4 |
| Ploidy | Same | Half |
| Identical | Yes | No |

slides.title: Division Quiz
slides.quizQuestion: How many daughter cells result from meiosis?

slides.title: Enzymes
slides.content:
# Enzymes

**Enzymes** are biological catalysts (usually proteins).

## How Enzymes Work:

1. Substrate binds to active site
2. Enzyme-substrate complex forms
3. Reaction occurs
4. Products released
5. Enzyme unchanged

## Models:

**Lock and Key:** Rigid fit
**Induced Fit:** Enzyme changes shape slightly

## Properties:
- Specific (one enzyme, one reaction)
- Reusable
- Not consumed
- Lower activation energy

## Factors Affecting:

| Factor | Effect |
|--------|--------|
| Temperature | Increases rate to optimum, then denatures |
| pH | Optimum varies by enzyme |
| Substrate conc | Increases rate until saturation |
| Enzyme conc | Increases rate |
| Inhibitors | Decrease rate |

## Inhibition:

**Competitive:**
- Inhibitor binds active site
- Competes with substrate

**Non-competitive:**
- Binds elsewhere (allosteric site)
- Changes enzyme shape

slides.title: Summary
slides.content:
# Cell Biology Summary

## Cell Structure:
- Prokaryotes: no nucleus
- Eukaryotes: membrane-bound organelles

## Key Organelles:
| Organelle | Function |
|-----------|----------|
| Nucleus | DNA storage, control |
| Mitochondria | ATP production |
| Ribosome | Protein synthesis |
| ER | Protein/lipid synthesis |
| Golgi | Packaging, modification |
| Chloroplast | Photosynthesis |

## Transport:
- Passive: No energy (diffusion, osmosis)
- Active: Requires ATP

## Energy:

| Process | Equation Summary |
|---------|-----------------|
| Respiration | Glucose + O2 -> CO2 + H2O + ATP |
| Photosynthesis | CO2 + H2O + Light -> Glucose + O2 |

## Cell Division:
| Type | Cells | Ploidy |
|------|-------|--------|
| Mitosis | 2 identical | Same |
| Meiosis | 4 different | Half |

> **Congratulations!** You've completed Cell Biology!
